Fuselage¶

class components.fuselage.fuselage.Fuselage(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This class will create a fuselage from frames created from desired internal components.

Returns:ParaPy Geometry of the Fuselage
Parameters:compartment_type (str list) – Type of containers at each station, possible entries (nose, container, motor, tail)
auto_fuselage_disable¶

Disables Automatic Fuselage Frame (FFrame) Creation and allows instead manual user-input to set the shape :type: bool

build_nose[source]¶

Switch case that that returns True/False if a nose is specified in compartment_type

Return type:bool
build_tail[source]¶

Switch case that that returns True/False if a tail is specified in compartment_type

Return type:bool
center_of_gravity[source]¶

Area weighted average of center of gravity

Returns:Position of the center of gravity in 3D space (x, y, z) w.r.t the origin XOY in [SI Meter]
Return type:Point
center_section[source]¶

The main output shape of the class Fuselage, constructed from the Private Attributes below

center_section_left[source]¶

The main fuselage section excluding nose and tail

center_section_right[source]¶

The mirror image of center_section_left since by definition half-frames are used

color¶

Sets the color of the fuselage (Overwritten from the default yellow) :type: str or Tuple

compartment_type¶

Type of containers at each station, possible entries (nose, container, motor, tail) :type: str list

component_type[source]¶

An identifier to be able to lump masses together. Possible entries: ‘wing’ ‘fuselage’ ‘vt’ ‘ht’ ‘ct’ ‘boom’ ‘payload’ ‘prop’ ‘battery’ ‘electronics’

Returns:Component Type
curves[source]¶

Grabs all curves out of the list frames

Returns:List of curves
Return type:list
external_shape[source]¶

The final shape of a ExternalSurface class which is to be exported THIS PART MUST BE OVERWRITTEN!!!

Returns:External Shape
Return type:Box
frame_builder[source]¶

This attribute codifies the knowledge for the fuselage and automatically generates the required frames by extracting the dimensions of the supplied sizing_parts’ through the methods `bbox_extractor and bbox_2_frame This has proven to be a very robust method since it does not depend on the complexity of the input part. Since these drones operate at very low mach numbers, the area rule which is commonly used for transonic aircraft is not valid. Instead these small drones can benefit from a lifting fuselage which is accomplished through having an airfoil like shape (thus a single location of maximum thickness). This location is referred to as the fuselage apex and is obtained by comparing the current frame to its sequential neighbor which links to a switch case, apex_reached and build_loc. A forward-chaining inference procedure is used in a for loop that traverses the fuselage from nose to tail and fires all fire-able rules sequentially. This procedure is preferred since multiple possibilities at each frame location exist (nose, container, motor, or tail) along with the same number of possibilities existing at the nearest neighbor. Finally, the start and end boundary conditions reject the creation of a nose or tail-cone before the fuselage is built, since both of these classes require tangency conditions at the start and end of the fuselage. Thus, the requested class is appended to a string array of still_to_build which is referenced later in the code.

Returns:A collection of frame variables that are used later in the fuselage class
Return type:dict
frames[source]¶

Collection of all center-fuselage section frames (those that were built by frame_builder. Each frame has an :attr: frame and :attr: points. If the user option minimize_frames is True then only the following frames are kept: [start, apex_start, apex_end, end].

Returns:List of center-fuselage section frames
Return type:list
fuselage_joiner[source]¶

Joines the current instantiated elements (nose/tail cone(s)) of the fuselage and outputs a single part

internal_shape[source]¶

This overwrites the Part defined in the class Component an internal_shape w/ a Dummy Value

make_transparent¶

Toggles transparency of the fuselage :type: bool

minimize_frames¶

Initiates the automatic frame minimization WARNING: May lead to intersecting surfaces :type: bool

nose[source]¶

Returns the nose cone of the fuselage is asked, otherwise returns a hidden circle. NOTE: This workaround was necessary to produce the parts in the tree, while still preserving lazy evaluation

pad_factor¶

Sets the Padding Factor between Fuselage Sizing Parts :type: bool

ply_number¶

Changes the number of ply’s of carbon fiber http://www.ijera.com/papers/Vol4_issue5/Version%202/J45025355.pdf :type: tuple

points[source]¶

Grabs all spline_points out of the list frames. Due to how the primitive class Frame is defined the significance of the points in order is as follows: Point 0 = Bottom (start), Point 1 = Right Side, Point 2 = Top (end), Point 3 = Left Side

Returns:List of spline_points in
ruled¶

Linearly joins the frames of the center fuselage WARNING: May lead to errors at the tail cone :type: bool

side_bc[source]¶

The side tangency boundary condition required for the fuselage nose and tail. This is obtained by fitting a curve through all side-points (Point 1 of Attribute points). Since, the fuselage shell is lofted from nose to tail (toward positive x) the start tangent and end tangents, obtained from a FittedCurve both face this direction. Thus, to create a nose cone, which has a build direction of x_ the direction of the start_tangent must be reversed. BC 0 = Start Tangent (Direction x_), BC 1 = End Tangent (Direction x).

Returns:List containing the start and end tangent vectors, and construction spline, included for debugging
Return type:Vector
tail[source]¶

Returns the tail cone of the fuselage is asked, otherwise returns a hidden circle. NOTE: This workaround was necessary to produce the parts in the tree, while still preserving lazy evaluation

top_bc[source]¶

The top tangency boundary condition required for the fuselage nose and tail. This is obtained by extracting the start and end tangents of the inner top edge from the attribute center_section_left. Keeping in-line with the definition of points in the frame primitives, the interpolated curve is conveniently constructed from the bottom point (Point 0) to the top point (Point 2). However, due to this convention the direction of the end tangent must be reversed.

Returns:List containing the start and end tangent vectors
Return type:Vector
transparency[source]¶

Switch case that returns the proper transparency value based on the status of show_internals

Returns:Transparency value
